Introduction

Hematuria, defined as the presence of red blood cells (RBCs) in the urine, can be gross (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic (detected only on microscopy).  It is seen in a variety of conditions ranging from benign to severe.  A systematic approach to evaluating hematuria includes confirming its presence, distinguishing glomerular from nonglomerular sources, and identifying the underlying cause through a targeted work-up.

Confirming hematuria

The initial step in evaluation of red or discolored urine is to confirm hematuria using urinalysis (UA).  In cases of microscopic hematuria detected incidentally, it is important to confirm the finding with a repeat urinalysis to rule out transient or spurious causes.  UA consists of dipstick analysis and microscopic examination.

Dipstick analysis

Urine dipstick is a convenient initial screening tool for blood in the urine:

  • Positive test:  Indicates the presence of heme, either from intact RBCs due to bleeding (true hematuria) or free hemoglobin/myoglobin due to hemolysis/rhabdomyolysis (false hematuria).  These should be differentiated with urine microscopy.
  • Negative test:  Suggests that red or discolored urine is not due to heme.  Causes include certain medications (eg, rifampin, phenazopyridine), food dye or beet ingestion, or other conditions (eg, porphyria).

Microscopic analysis

Microscopy confirms true hematuria by identifying â‰¥3 RBCs/hpf.  It also helps determine the origin of hematuria:

  • Dysmorphic RBCs:  Suggest a glomerular source, as RBCs become irregularly shaped when passing through a damaged glomerular filtration barrier.  RBC casts further support a glomerular etiology, as casts form within renal tubules when there is renal parenchymal inflammation or damage.
  • Normal-appearing RBCs:  Indicate a nonglomerular source, with RBCs maintaining a uniform shape due to minimal distortion during transit.

Glomerular vs nonglomerular hematuria

After confirming hematuria, distinguishing between glomerular and nonglomerular sources guides the differential diagnosis and subsequent work-up (

Glomerular hematuria

Glomerular hematuria originates from the glomeruli, where RBCs squeeze through a compromised capillary wall due to inflammation (ie, glomerulonephritis) or structural abnormalities (eg, thin basement membrane disease).  This results in deformed (dysmorphic) RBCs and formation of RBC casts within renal tubules.

The urine may appear normal visually (ie, microscopic hematuria), grossly bloody (when RBCs are abundant), or reddish-brown or cola-colored (chemical changes due to methemoglobin formation from prolonged transit time and acidic pH).  Blood clots are usually absent.  Examples include:

  • IgA nephropathy:  Glomerular IgA deposition causes episodic gross hematuria following upper respiratory infections.
  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis:  Glomerulonephritis can occur after certain infections (eg, streptococcal pharyngitis), presenting with hematuria, edema, and hypertension.
  • Lupus nephritis:  Immune complex deposition leads to hematuria and other extrarenal manifestations of systemic lupus erythematosus (eg, malar rash, joint pain).
  • Thin basement membrane disease:  Thin basement membrane disease is typically benign and often familial, presenting with isolated microscopic hematuria.
  • Alport syndrome:  Alport syndrome is due to a genetic defect in type IV collagen affecting the glomerular basement membrane; it classically manifests in the kidneys (hematuria) and ears (hearing loss).

Nonglomerular hematuria

Nonglomerular hematuria arises from the renal parenchyma or lower urinary tract without glomerular involvement (ie, normal-appearing RBCs).  The urine is usually pink or bright red due to abundant RBCs, indicating fresh blood without significant chemical alteration.  Blood clots may be present.  Etiologies include:

  • Nephrolithiasis (kidney stones):  Characterized by flank/abdominal pain and hematuria (often gross)
  • Urinary tract infection (UTI):  Presents with dysuria, frequency, and hematuria
  • Urothelial (bladder) cancer:  Typically presents as painless gross hematuria in older adults with risk factors (eg, smoking)
  • Renal tumors:  Malignancies (eg, renal cell carcinoma) that can cause hematuria
  • Polycystic kidney disease:  Characterized by renal cysts that may bleed
  • Renal papillary necrosis:  Due to infarction of renal papillae in certain situations (eg, sickle cell disease, analgesic overuse)
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia:  Common in older men, often causing microscopic hematuria due to vascular engorgement from obstruction
  • Trauma:  Includes genitourinary injuries, pelvic fractures, or exercise-induced hematuriaâ€“a benign condition caused by bladder microtrauma after strenuous activities (eg, long-distance running)

Diagnostic evaluation and management

Distinguishing between glomerular and nonglomerular directs the subsequent diagnostic approach.  A history and physical examination can identify certain clues, including recent strenuous exercise, UTI symptoms, and risk factors (eg, smoking).  False hematuria (eg, hemoglobinuria, medications, foods) should be excluded to avoid unnecessary testing.  Patients on an anticoagulant or antiplatelet agent require the same evaluation as those not on these medications.

Glomerular hematuria

When a glomerular cause is suspected, evaluation focuses on identifying underlying renal pathology.

Serum laboratory tests include:

  • Renal function tests:  Serum blood urine nitrogen and creatinine assess renal function, which can range from mildly impaired to renal failure.
  • Complement levels (C3, C4):  Decreased levels suggest immune complex-mediated diseases (eg, postinfectious glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis), except in IgA nephropathy where complement levels are usually normal (
    figure 1
    ).
  • Autoantibodies:  These include antinuclear antibodies and antiâ€“double-stranded DNA for lupus, anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies for Goodpasture syndrome, and antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies for vasculitides.

A renal biopsy is generally required in cases of glomerular hematuria, especially if associated with other nephritic syndrome features (eg, proteinuria, renal dysfunction).  Biopsy results provide a definitive diagnosis and guide treatment decisions.  Glomerulonephritis is often treated with immunosuppressive therapy (eg, glucocorticoids), blood pressure control, and management of volume overload.

Nonglomerular hematuria

For suspected nonglomerular causes, evaluation targets urologic abnormalities.  The timing of gross hematuria during voiding can sometimes serve as a clue, as it can reflect where the blood originated or has concentrated the most (

figure 2
).  However, in most cases, further evaluation is necessary, namely in the form of imaging and, in some instances, cystoscopy.

Imaging studies include:

  • CT urography:  CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast is usually first-line and has largely replaced intravenous pyelograms.  It is particularly helpful for detecting tumors and stones.
  • Ultrasonography:  This is less sensitive than CT scan but avoids radiation and is useful in pregnant patients and children.
  • MR urography:  An alternative to CT, it avoids radiation exposure and is particularly helpful in pregnant patients or children with hydronephrosis seen on ultrasonography.

Cystoscopy, the gold standard for diagnosing bladder cancer, is an endoscopic technique that allows direct visualization of the bladder and urethra (

).  Urine cytology to detect malignant cells is no longer routinely performed given its variable sensitivity and specificity.Specific pathway examples of nonglomerular hematuria include:

  • If nephrolithiasis is suspected (flank pain, known history of stones):
    • Confirm with imaging, typically noncontrast CT or ultrasound.
    • Management may involve hydration, alpha blockers, pain control, and urology evaluation if obstruction is present.
  • If UTI is suspected (dysuria, frequency, positive dipstick):
    • Confirm with urine culture.
    • Treat with appropriate antibiotics; re-evaluate if hematuria persists.
  • If malignancy is suspected (painless gross hematuria, age >50, smoking history):
    • Cystoscopy is warranted to visually inspect the bladder and obtain biopsies if needed.

Summary

Hematuria, characterized by red blood cells in the urine, necessitates a systematic approach to identify its origin and cause.  Initial confirmation via urinalysis distinguishes true hematuria from false hematuria due to a positive dipstick result from hemoglobinuria/myoglobinuria.  Microscopic examination reveals whether red blood cells are dysmorphicâ€“suggesting a glomerular source (eg, IgA nephropathy, postinfectious)â€“or normal-shaped, indicating nonglomerular causes (eg, bladder cancer, urinary tract infection).  Glomerular hematuria often has microscopic hematuria (cola-colored urine), while nonglomerular hematuria typically results in gross hematuria (pink or bright red urine).  Diagnostic steps include serum tests and potential renal biopsy for glomerulonephritis, and imaging studies or cystoscopy for nonglomerular conditions, guiding targeted management.
